Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) for Performing Multidisciplinary Research at Delaware State University Imaging Facility
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical: This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) grant awarded to Delaware State University (DSU) provides funding for the acquisition of a Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM). This high-resolution imaging microscope enhances the research and educational capabilities at DSU, a historically-black university with a large pool of talented students who have been traditionally underrepresented in the fields of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM). Thanks to this acquisition, DSU STEM students get "hands on" experience and training in this broadly-used technology. Further, the SEM is an impetus to stimulate new opportunities, and to develop new collaborative projects among DSU and non-DSU researchers. Most particularly, it strengthens the mission of the NSF-funded Center for Research Excellence in Science and Technology at DSU: the Optical Science Center for Applied Research.

Technical: The goals of this MRI project are: (1) to develop and design novel materials for integrated circuits and their applications, (2) to assess the efficiency of (Deoxyribonucleic acid) DNA delivery systems, (3) to understand the estrogen receptors in goldfish, and (4) to characterize and probe the nanoscopic structures of diverse biopolymers. In addition, the instrument provides other capabilities such as energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy microanalysis system, which can be used to determine the elemental composition of a specimen. Thus, the instrument contributes to the successful realization of various ongoing research projects at DSU, including: i) the fabrication of a nanofiber in situ electroporation chip to deliver DNA into cells, ii) the study of membrane-associated estrogen receptors in the Mauthner cell circuit of goldfish, and iii) the characterization of tubulin nanorings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merits:

1. InAsN thin films deposited by Pulsed Laser Depostion (PLD) and Metal Organic Chemical Vapor Deposition (MOCVD) techniques had been investigated for some of their electrical and optical properties to use them as transistor materials in the power amplifier circuit of RF amplifier.  Energy dispersive spectroscopy function of SEM was used to determine the atomic composition of the film while the electron microscope was used to look at the film morphology.  This work was done in collaboration with an SBIR company funded by NSF.

2. Nanofiber in-situ electroporation chip was faricated for DNA delivery.  The chip was fabricated on glass substrate with Au thin film for electroporation.  Polycarprolactone (PCL) was electropsun as paralled-aligned nanofiber membranes directly on the glass chip.  SEM was used to look at the alignment of the PCL nanofiber and re-aligned after looking the under SEM.

3. Steroid hormone estrogen in the Mauthner cell circuit of the goldfish had been investigated and SEM micrograph showed the presence of cholesterol in the gold fish brain.

4. Ca modified lead titanate thin films were investigated for some of their electrical and optical properties and SEM was used to look at the film morphology and atomic composition.

5. Aluminum nitride thin films were investigated for some of their electrial and optical properties and SEM was used to look at the film morphology and atomic composition.

6. Sn doped GeSiO thin films were investigated for some of their electrical and optical properties and SEM was used to look at the film morphology and atomic composition

7. Food borne pathogens (Salmonella typhimurium) had been investigated in fluidic media.

Broader Impact:

1. The microscope had been integrated with education and course work at Delaware State University (DSU) and at least fifteen undergraduate students were trained though the course "Quantitative Optical Methods and Microscopy".  Most of these students are from underrepresented groups of STEM.

2. Seven graduate students from different research groups and five faculty members were trained to ue the mocroscope.

3. The acquisition of the SEM enhanced the scope of the DSU Imaging Facility by training of undergraduate and graduate students in imaging science and strengthen the research infrastructure in terms of advancded imaging and also enhance the graduate programs in optical sciences, chemistry, agriculture and biology.  Last year at least five faculty members other than the PIs and co-Pls used the SEM for their work.

4. The SEM provided sustainability to the DESU imaging facility by generating more than $4,000 in user fees.

5. The SEM helped to publish three refereed conference proceedings and Journals, seven Refereed oral presentations and posters, one thesis disseratation, four non-refereed oral presentations and posters all of whom are co-authored by students.

6. The SEM had been an attractive tool for demonstrations to kids of local schools/community colleges during their visit and potential future students during the open house of the university.
